**BANKING HOUSE**

Macarthur & Knowles,
Prince Albert, N.W.T.

**PRINCE ALBERT, N. W. T., FRIDAY, MARCH 28, 1884.**

**COMMUNICATIONS.**

**FIRE PROTECTION.**

_To the Editor of The Times._

Sir,—I was pleased to read in The Times of the 21st that we were in a fair way to be incorporated. I have no doubt that the first important business that will engage the attention of the council will be that of fire protection. I trust the lease taken by Mr. Smith for the fire hall will not be neglected. Although the fire company were early in attendance with what apparatus they had, and worked hard and efficiently, there was nothing to show by citizens, etc., all they could do was to save the store house. The mill had to go, and I am afraid, also, the lumber yard. If a spark, a clean engine thrown two streams had been on hand, all before the men came, and thus saved the cost of his fine engine. Another matter, gunpowder is kept in large quantities, and if the fire should break out, so kept that it can be easily got at and removed in case of fire, as great loss of life may result in case of fire.

Respectfully,

JOHN F. KENNEDY, Sec.

**CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.**

_Gathered by our Reporters._

Mr. Wm. Gordon got back from Troy on Monday last.

See Wm. Croat's going advertising in another column.

Mr. Allan Clark has arrived back home from Fort Pittage last Monday.

The next session of the North West Council will be held in July next.

The weather has almost disappeared here for a few days. The spring is coming on.

Mr. Allan Clark has started back home.

There will be a meeting of the Prince Albert Fire Co. at Mr. Garcia's workshop this evening, at 7:30 sharp. Business is important.

Seeds—Alex Clark & Co., family chemists, have just received a large selection of seeds from Mr. E. Smith in Cal. Smith's report.

There will be a meeting of the Prince Albert Fire Co. at Mr. Garcia's workshop this evening, at 7:30 sharp. Business is important.

Seeds—Alex Clark & Co., family chemists, have just received a large selection of seeds from Mr. E. Smith in Cal. Smith's report.

A requisition is being taken round for signatures for Mr. E. Smith to stand forward as a candidate for mayor in the event of incorporation.

The Hon. Alexander Macdonald will hold the first of many annual meetings on May 27th next, when a good programme will be offered.

His Lordship, the Bishop of Saskatchewan, has approved the Rev. E. Parker Smith's request (Humility) for the Rev. H. G. P. Cameron's admission to the status of Anglican after Eastern Rite.

The Hon. J. M. Johnson, president of the Saskatchewan Curling Club, has sent from the Hon. L. Clarke, patron of the club, two beautiful silver bowls mounted with silver cups as prizes, which will be given to the members of the Saskatcheawin Club, and the other to the members of the Argyle Club who win the annual sweepstakes.

The 17th annual of the C. M. Clarke musical programme is under the able direction of Mr. J. M. Johnson, and the orchestra conducted by Mr. J. M. Johnson, the choir will be directed by Mr. J. M. Johnson.

CURLING.

Yesterday an annual bonspiel was held on the river rink, the members of both the Saskatchewan and Argyle clubs, parading their prowess in the art of curling, which is not a rare accomplishment, but a very few of us have seen anything like that in years past.

The Argyle club beat the Saskatcheawin 21, leaving the latter club winners by three points.

**TELEGRAFIQUE.**

_HOUSE STILL IN SESSION._

_No Business of Importance last Week—Budget Speech Tomorrow._

_Immigrants arriving from Ontario._

_Railway Collision—Passengers Injured._

_Mild Weather in Manitoba._

_Sir Charles Tupper will oppose San Francisco, Winnipeg and H.B. Railway._

_The Opposition to take up Manitoban Grievances._

_Debate on Prohibition—Vote in Favor decided by Large Majority._

_Sir John A. M. Seriously Ill._

_Philanthropic Advertised Exhibition of Good Old Ideas._

_Heavy Floods at London._

_Toronto Bribe Case Still Going on in Federal Court._

_Destroying Evidence Against Mayor Talk of Arrest._

_Experiment Increasing in the Damaging Facts come out._

_The Ontario Parliament Proceeded._

_Terrorized Streetcar of G. B. R. Employers._

_Advance at British Relieved by Strikers' Large Number of Demonstrators._

_Scenes—Terrific Clashes—Horses, Trains and Characters—Great Loss of Life._

_By Special Telegraph to The Times._

_WINNIPEG, March 27th.—The Local House is still in Session. Nothing of the matter. There is a great deal of excitement, mostly private bills. Premier Norquay will make his budget speech tomorrow.

A large number of immigrants are arriving from Ontario and England.

On Wednesday a train of twenty-eight cars of immigrants and baggage left for Portage la Prairie. Hope, with about thirty passengers was run into by an express train near St. Paul. The coaches of Settlers' Express were badly injured, and the passengers severely injured, and taken to the hospital at St. Paul.

The weather is cool and rainy. The land has been badly damaged.

_Ottawa_, March 27th.—Sir Charles Tupper may be opposed the passage of the San Francisco, Winnipeg and Hudson Bay Railway bill.

The opposition bring up Manitoban grievances to day.

A long debate on prohibition occurred yesterday in favor of it was defeated by eighty-two.

Sir Leonard Tilley voted against prohibition. He said he had heard the effects of the law in New Brunswick, and that worse evils existed there than now under the beverage laws.

Mr. A. Macdonald is seriously ill, and unable to sit in Parliament.

_Toronto_, March 27th.—The question of prohibition is being strongly advocated here.

The prohibitionists are asking that the Scott act be submitted to the electors all over the Dominion simultaneously.

Heavy floods at London, and the river rising.

The Kingston Road bridge has been seriously damaged.

The trial of Bandits, Kirkland, Monk and others, at the Police Court, is still going on. Kirkland has been bailed by Mr. Goldwin Smith. Several cases evi-

Quota a number of hanging dogs have been found on the property of Mr. Brewer, where a public dinner house is intended to be erected by the settlers of the town. The dogs were killed by the tenants of the place for his groceries. Mr. Goldwin Smith said that he knew Charles Grant was arrested again for killing a horse, after killing the horse of Mr. Herbert. Peter killed five mouses.

AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW
SPINK & MAVEETY
T. H. SPINK
PRINCE ALBERT, N. W. T.

THE HUDSON BAY ROUTE
That nameless working steadily at surely as it has been gathering the course of slowly passing ages has silently accumulating in these Territories a rich abundance of all things suited to the requirements of civilized man. We have no cause to open our dispute. That the discovery of this fact should have been made just as signs of share, if slow, decayin the older inhabited portions of the North appear to us to be fraught with that reaction in the condition of society caused by the rapidly increasing practical application to the wants of man of old world scientific discoveries, not without a large significance in casting the horoscope of our prosperity in this vast country. What, however, more immediately and intimately concerns us just now is the question as to how we are to secure to ourselves the greatest possible benefits which ought justly to reward our enterprise, our labors and services privations as the pioneers of civilization? The answer to this most vital question seems far to seek. Indicating the depression, necessary consequent upon hopes and schemes allowed to run riot, owing to the fact that the immigration of our kind has been on such a scale that in a short while consumers of produce have already so far outstripped supply beyond the means that an unmitigated surplus is absolutely necessary for our salvation. It seems almost superfluous to add that nothing but the steady demand for timber in the provinces may see a legitimate one to them, but they must distinctly understand that we do not intend to form the subject of our own experiment. The refusal to deem our lives to be worth our own expenditure seems selfish, but we can't help it. The solution of the Hudson Straits question seems to us to mean life or death for the settlers. While quite aware that mere personal denunciation can carry no great weight either way, we must say that a careful examination of the facts so far adduced strongly tends to strengthen our conviction of the practicality of the route, the more so, as we notice that a contrary view is supported by a great extent of men who until recently succeeded in convincing Europe that this country was useless unless for fur trading. That idea is already a tradition, and we believe that the importance of the profits only realized by the Hudson Bay Company will soon be relegated to the same category. Space only permits us to glance at this large question, and as probably all that can so far be said about it is not yet altogether discussed, we pass on with solemn regard to this matter being scrutinized. That their conduct with respect to other matters is subjected to the same feeling they must be aware, and we trust that by refusing to pander to the selfish interests of the opponents of this scheme, they may succeed in creating much existing bitterness. The conduct of the C.P.R. authorities seems to bear out our expectations that so far from opposing the movement, they are doing all in their power to facilitate the prosperity of the Territories as a whole and their own must be mutually involved. We believe that anything they may lose by the emergence of the new line in the eastern portion of their line, where they have to contend with powerful opposition, will before long be more than compensated for by the increased traffic on the new line, which must be of most important link in the communication between the Pacific Ocean and Europe. That must jealously should exist in and around the Hudson Bay Provinces is a fear, is incredible, but we believe the proportion of that antagonism, and the benefits certain to accrue to us from the completion of the railway will be more than the risk. We would humbly advise its opponents to give in gracefully, to resign themselves to the inevitable. They can only hope at most to retard for a time what is a foregone conclusion, and moreover, create much bitterness in those whose prosperity, we might say very existence, depends upon the speedy opening of the route to the West. Meanwhile we earnestly hope that the people of Manitoba and the North West Territories will sink all other differences for the present and to a large extent, in the support of their leaders in carrying through, as compared with which all else sinks into insignificance.

With regard to Mr. D. Cameron's story as told in his letter, we consider it an imperative public duty to point out the significance of his statement. He has stated that the entry of his land has been productive except from Crown Timber Agent for whom he claims on logs cut under circumstances described in his letter. Putting aside the question of a timber agent's right to enter a settler's land on us under our peculiar circumstances, it is to be tolerated that a proper share of the timber industry is to call us to account. The timber cut several years ago, at a time when there was no timber agent in the District, if even in the Territories? In those days a settler would have just as soon been asked to lend a person's cattle at the rate of a penny. We believe this action to be ultra vires, even had they had the decency to hear Cameron's side of the case. If the matter cannot, unless Cameron can produce a receipt for an unsubstantiated claim of a totally uncertain amount, he may have been jumped and lost the use of ten years' labor and prison. The thin thread is the fact of it all ugly look of tyranny. It would look as if the Timber Agent, ashamed of his actions, had recourse to something not unlike a conspiracy to bulldoze. Perhaps, though, he can explain. We trust he will do so and that people here realize whether their position is to be under police officers, Crown timber or other agents, analogous to that of Russian serfs.

THE HORSE SHOE STORE

There is a motto that's plain if you follow
You will find in the end it will pay.
Success will come if you make efforts anew,
A result that answered in event that is gained
When buying your property go where they say.

At the store they call the "Horse Shoe."
It is not only cents but dollars you will save.
Will leave you a hundred more to the good
Remember the motto and also the place,
And you'll be glad you've bought there.

We are determined to sell out at occasional Hard Lines.
Better tuck next time.

The Boom is of

What cannot be avoided
Twice children's weaknesses to lament.
How often in affairs of men we do
Fail limitation end in worst failure?
If trouble must be made, decide at once,
And with proceeds of the sale buy cheaper.

G. BLACKETT & CO.,
J. A. Scott & Co.,
Toronto.

PUBLIC NOTICE:

All persons are hereby required to take notice that the cutting of timber as the public lands of Canada, without the permission of the Minister of the Interior or the Local Agent, is prohibited by law, and all timber so cut without such permission is liable to seizure, and to be dealt with as the Minister of the Interior may direct.

Each settler on a homestead quarter-section not having timber land, must notify the Minister of the Interior, or the Agent of the Dominion Lands, purchase a wood lot not exceeding five acres, at twenty-five cents per acre.

Any person other than a homestead settler desiring permission to cut timber, must notify the Minister of the Interior, or the Agent of the Interior, who will deal with the matter.

Persons who have already cut timber, must notify the Minister of the Interior, or the Agent of the Interior, who will deal with the matter.

Notice is hereby given that the Crown Timber Agent at his office will be open from the 1st May, otherwise the said time will be extended under the provisions of Land Act's.

D. J. WATSON, Crown Timber Agent.

STRAVED

On the premises of the undersigned, about a month ago, a black brown mare about a year old, feet and face white.

The owner can have her by paying cost. If not claimed before the expiry of two months will be sold to pay expenses.

T. N. ISBISTER, South Branch.

OFFICE NO. 208.

Near Presbyterian Church.
H. B. ROUTE AGAIN.

J. Lemire, of Long Lake, sailed from St. John's in the "H. B. Co. ship Prince of Wales," for York Factory. Had mild weather and a pleasant trip all the way out. Saw the steamer "Nipigon" account-
ing Cape Resolution, at the entrance to Hudson's straits, about the last of June. Could not get through the narrows at that time. There was consid-
erable fog, but the ship did not lie up,
was so low in the straits that the boat-
men could see over her deck, and the
weather and navigation good. Only
difficulty, the current was strong and not
properly known; it had to be kept well astern
to keep the vessel going. When
there was a tide with a copper wave so that it
would give the true direction. When
near the entrance, there was a sudden
attention of Equinaxus, but no cause
for alarm. After passing through the
straits about August 1st, went south-
eastward between Manfield
island and the main land. There en-
countered fine flow, and smooth water.
The turn of the tide released the vessel, and no
more ice was seen. The weather was
unusually calm and fine. No Indians
were seen in the straits or bay, and there
are no violent storms.

Launched at York Factory on August 15th. About seven miles out
from York, and in low tide the vessels
have only room to swing, with bare sand
banks on either side.

Mr. Lemire remained at York factory
during the years '62, '63 and part of '64,
the ships being laid up during those
three weeks, leaving for England about
the middle of September. Ice took
York river early last October, '64, and
kept gradually freezing further down
the river until winter. Although open water could not
be seen in the head of the river, the snow
and ice was very heavy. The
weather was generally dead calm and
very cold, the thermometer frequently
reading below zero, and sometimes six
feet deep. All winters similar in char-
acter. Spring thaw commenced at
the latter part of April or first of May.
York river opens about May 30th, and
the hay clear of snow about June 10th.
Vehicles can travel before York river
breaks a passage through the ice to
the open water. The fish are white
generally, but are very thick along the shores.
The summer season is generally very
late. June 1st thermometer regis-
tered 100° in the shade. Turnips and radishes grow well at
the fort and potatoes have been tried, but
only grown in small quantities. There
was frost in June and July.

After leaving York Mr. Lemire resided
in the Rainy Lake district for several
years. In 1870, the steamer last, of
"H. B." took passage in a new vessel called
the Prince Rupert. Mr. Lemire, Eng. Saws a
great deal of the country, and has visited
reaching Manfield island. Passed
the island in the night, five days out from
York. Saw no ice along the shores or
in the straits. Had no fog, as there
are none in the fall. Passed cape Resolu-
tion north, about July 15th. York. Kept
north about three weeks. York river
gales across the ocean, and no ice.
Left the best India dock, London,
twenty-five afters noon.

Left Stromness again for the North
West on June 18th, 1870, in the Prince
Rupert. Eng. Saws a great deal of the
country, and has visited reaching Manfield island. Passed
the island in the night, five days out from
York. Saw no ice along the shores or
in the straits. Had no fog, as there
are none in the fall. Passed cape Resolu-
tion north, about July 15th. York. Kept
north about three weeks. York river
gales across the ocean, and no ice.
Left the best India dock, London,
twenty-five afters noon.

Left Stromness again for the North
West on June 18th, 1870, in the Prince
Rupert. Eng. Saws a great deal of the
country, and has visited reaching Manfield island. Passed
the island in the night, five days out from
York. Saw no ice along the shores or
in the straits. Had no fog, as there
are none in the fall. Passed cape Resolu-
tion north, about July 15th. York. Kept
north about three weeks. York river
gales across the ocean, and no ice.
Left the best India dock, London,
twenty-five afters noon.

The trip is usually made by the
"H. B." ships in from five to eight
weeks, and the return in from thirty
to thirty-five weeks. Weather good all
the time. By mistake reached Sugar
trees on the coast, far west of York near-
est York, but returned to York next day,
six weeks and a day from Stromness.
After entering the bay on this trip, met
and Yankee, Capt. Johnson, who had
tried the bay three weeks before and
had seen no ice while passing through the
straits.

The next trip is usually made by the
"H. B." ships in from five to eight
weeks, and the return in from thirty
to thirty-five weeks. Weather good all
the time. By mistake reached Sugar
trees on the coast, far west of York near-
est York, but returned to York next day,
six weeks and a day from Stromness.
After entering the bay on this trip, met
and Yankee, Capt. Johnson, who had
tried the bay three weeks before and
had seen no ice while passing through the
straits.
ITEMS OF INTEREST.

THE VERY LATEST NEWS.

CANADIAN.

PORTSMOUTH, FRIDAY, March 15.—R. R. Marshall has purchased H. R. Banks' lumber yard, through the Ontario Bank.

A successful carnival, the largest ever held in this city, was held last night at George Craig's yard.

George Craig has made arrangements to supply newspapers with goods.

STEVENSON CITY, N. W. T., March 15.—An election meeting of citizens was held last night to consider the means of establishing a newspaper. The greatest enthusiasm prevailed throughout the town, and a substantial sum of money was raised.

Mr. Stevenson, formerly manager of Grey's Tobacco Factory, has been elected president of the association. The plant is to be procured as soon as possible, and the Silver City Press will be located here.

The election was held May 15.

MONTREAL, March 14.—The Canada Guv'nor contains a dispatch from A. B. Murray, of St. Boniface, at present third commissioner under the McNally Act, for the liquor license district of Portage la Prairie, to the effect that he has been appointed to the same district, and Joseph F. Tremblay to be the third commissioner for the same district.

It was rumoured at the time that Mr. Murray had received an intimation to use every precaution, as dynamiters were supposed to be gathering together on the building site.

The guard was increased, and the Speaker of the Commons and others who were appointed to the building site retired from their quarters on Saturday evening. It is said, however, that Mr. Murray left early owing to his being ill.

Montreal, March 15.—The Canadian Pacific has reduced freight rates on grain shipped from Chicago to 2 cents per hundred pounds.

TOMATOES, March 15.—The tomato crop is reported to be very good, and the market is expected to be active.

ST. LOUIS, March 15.—A gas explosion occurred in the Liberal Club building today, killing all the members in the building and several others outside.

Winnipeg, March 16.—This morning at 8 o'clock two prisoners confined in the Provincial jailhouse and the jailer and family occupied a brickyard were captured. Later advice states that one of them was captured, and the other is thought to have been severely wounded by the jibes.

Last night three men, coloured, got into the former's mistress' house and threw a lamp striking Scott on the head and breaking the lamp. The oil took fire and Scott was badly burned. One was arrested.

AMERICAN.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 16.—At the Pantages' opera last night a tragic accident occurred. Mrs. Harris was acting as usher when she fell and was killed, and her body was thrown into the orchestra pit.

NEW YORK, March 16.—A prize fight for $500 between Hogan and Hart was fought today on a barge which was towed across East River. Hogan won in four rounds.

ST. LOUIS, March 16.—Arrangements are being made for an international bear show of dogs, to be held here about the middle of April.

NASHVILLE, KY., March 16.—The Quaker City is reported to be engaged in killing and burning of seven head out of the Owl Creek herd.

Davenport, March 16.—On June 1st, 1867, Charlotte Kate, a pretty girl, 18 years old, was murdered in her home on Oak Street by a man named Harris. The murderer said yesterday that he had killed her because she had confessed that her own mother had committed adultery.

PLATTSBURGH, March 16.—A Walnut street, Marshall County, two men were killed by a horse which was running loose. One of the victims was identified as Haggard, who drank and walked to clean out John Cherriman's saloon. Our knockdown Cherriman down and the other knocked him down. Cherriman, who was drunk, shot Harris dead and put two balls into Hardman's head, from which he died three days later.

NEW ORLEANS, March 16.—From Sharkey County, Mississippi, came the news that Greenwood, 100 miles below, the water is over all places except a few mounds sufficient for stock to stand on. The town of Greenwood is now a sea except a warehouse and the court house. Shell Mounds and Slides are both overflown. No loss of life or stock has yet been reported.

GENERAL.

LONDON, Eng., March 15.—The Commons continued in session all night debating the Egyptian question.

It is rumored that the Government desiring to test the opinion of the country in regard to their Egyptian policy has sent a special agent to Egypt and informed the Queen of this decision.

DELAWARE, March 17.—The counties of Tyrone, Clinton, Susquehanna and Northumberland have been declared under the Reims Act in view of possible riots today.

Paris, March 16.—The French advance from Rich Nain has begun. Gen. Desaix marches upon Thudupurin, and General Ney marches upon Langres.

The Government has instructed Gen. Millet commander of the land forces in Tonquin, not to cease military operations against Thudupurin and Longchon. Prime Minister Ferry has responded direct negotiations with Marquis Tung for a treaty based upon the conditions that the French be allowed to retain possession of Rich Nain.

Havana, March 15.—(i.e.), Velarde, a cavalry officer, three sailors and twenty-five civilians were arrested at General Velarde's house on Saturday, and were taken to Havana and other places, including Belgrano Villa Campa. The Government has given no time being given for a military uprising similar to that of August last. Many more persons were arrested today.

Buenos Aires, March 15.—A meeting of the Progressives today to resolve to pass with the Liberal Union was adopted.

U.S. President Grant has accepted Prince Albert's invitation to dinner on the 23rd with the Empress William.

HUDSON'S BAY CO'Y

FARMING LANDS!

FOR SALE IN

Manitoba & North-west

The Hudson's Bay Company owns 7,000,000 acres in the Great Fertile Belt, and now offer for sale 500,000 acres, already surveyed by the Government of Canada.

ALSO

TOWN LOTS FOR SALE

In Winnipeg, West Lynne, Rat Portage, Portage la Prairie and Goschen, N.W.T.

The above will be disposed of at reasonable prices and on easy terms of payment.

Full information in regard to these lands will be given at the offices of the Company in Winnipeg and Montreal.

C. J. BRUGES, Land Commissioner.
